Custom Domain Setup for AI Website Builders

Your AI-generated site comes with a ugly subdomain. Framer gives you yoursite.framer.ai. Durable gives yoursite.durable.co. You need yoursite.com. Here's the step-by-step process for each major builder.

Before you start: You need to own a domain. Buy one from Namecheap (~$10/year), Google Domains (~$12/year), or GoDaddy (~$15/year). Avoid buying through the AI builder—they often markup prices. Buy separately, connect it yourself. It's easy and saves money.

Framer AI: Custom domain setup

Framer makes this straightforward. The process takes about 15 minutes, mostly waiting for DNS propagation.

Step-by-step process

  1. [object Object]
  2. [object Object]
  3. [object Object]

Important: Keep your domain registered at your registrar. Don't transfer it to Framer. Just connect it via DNS records. This makes it easier to switch platforms later if needed.

Troubleshooting Framer domains: If verification fails, wait 30 minutes and try again—DNS propagation can take time. Make sure you added the exact records Framer showed you. If using CNAME, some registrars require you to leave the "host" or "name" field blank or enter "@". Read your registrar's help docs if stuck.

Durable AI: Custom domain setup

Durable's process is similar to Framer. The UI is slightly different but the DNS concepts are identical.

Step-by-step process

  1. [object Object]
  2. [object Object]
  3. [object Object]

Note: Durable also offers to buy the domain through them. It's faster but more expensive. I recommend buying separately and connecting—it's cheaper and you retain control.

Troubleshooting Durable domains: Durable's DNS records can be finicky. Make sure you're using the exact record type they show (CNAME vs A record). Some registrars require different formats. Contact Durable support if verification fails after an hour—they're responsive.

10Web AI: Custom domain setup

10Web uses standard WordPress domain mapping. You're connecting a domain to a WordPress site, which is a well-documented process.

Step-by-step process

  1. [object Object]
  2. [object Object]
  3. [object Object]

WordPress advantage: Since 10Web is WordPress, you can also use WordPress plugins for domain management. Some users find this easier than DNS records.

Troubleshooting 10Web domains: 10Web hosts on Google Cloud, so you're adding DNS records that point to their infrastructure. The A record they provide is static. If you have trouble, 10Web support can access your site and fix DNS issues directly—they can log in and configure it for you.

Common DNS issues (and how to fix them)

Issue: Domain not verifying after 30 minutes

Causes: DNS propagation delay, wrong record type, typo in records, cached DNS at your ISP.

Fix: Wait another hour. Try verifying from a different network (phone WiFi vs home internet). Use a DNS checker tool like whatsmydns.net to see if your records are propagating globally. Double-check you copied the exact records from the AI builder.

Issue: Site works on www but not root domain

Cause: Only added CNAME for www.yoursite.com, didn't add A record or CNAME for yoursite.com.

Fix: Add DNS records for both versions. Most AI builders show records for both www and non-www. Add both to your registrar. Or set up a redirect so one version forwards to the other.

Issue: SSL certificate not working

Cause: SSL requires DNS to be fully propagated first. Can take up to 24 hours, though usually 10-30 minutes.

Fix: Wait longer. Make sure your domain is verified first—SSL won't work until DNS is correctly configured. If still broken after 24 hours, contact support. Most AI builders use Let's Encrypt which is free and automatic once DNS is correct.

Issue: Want to use email with custom domain

Solution: Set up email separately. Google Workspace ($6/user/month), Zoho Mail (free for up to 5 users), or Fastmail ($3-5/month). You'll add MX records to your DNS configuration. The AI builder doesn't handle email—your domain registrar or email provider does.

Should you buy through the AI builder?

All three builders offer to sell you a domain directly. It's faster—one-click setup. But I don't recommend it. Here's why:

  • Price markup: Builders charge $15-25/year. Registrars charge $10-15/year. Small difference but adds up.
  • Lock-in: If your domain is tied to the builder, leaving is harder. Separate registrar = easier to switch platforms.
  • Management: Registrars give better DNS management tools. Builder interfaces are basic.
  • Bundle pricing: Some registrars offer free privacy protection, email forwarding, or other perks. Builders often charge extra.

Recommendation: Buy at Namecheap or Google Domains. Connect manually. Takes 15 extra minutes, saves money, and keeps you in control.

Bottom line

Custom domain setup is straightforward once you understand DNS. Buy your domain separately, add the DNS records your builder shows you, wait for propagation, verify. The entire process takes 15-30 minutes.

If you run into issues, all three builders have support teams who can help. But 95% of problems are user error—wrong record type, typo in records, not waiting long enough for propagation. Follow the steps exactly and it will work.
